newsitem.title: USA: NCAA BASKETBALL-ARIZONA STUNS KANSAS, NORTH CAROLINA HOLDS OFF CALIFORNIA.
newsitem.headline: NCAA BASKETBALL-ARIZONA STUNS KANSAS, NORTH CAROLINA HOLDS OFF CALIFORNIA.

text.p: Top-ranked Kansas, the one team in the 64-school NCAA men's basketball tournament that seemed to have a lock on a Final Four berth, was stunned by fourth-seeded Arizona in the Southeast regional semifinals on Friday.
Freshman Mike Bibby scored 21 points and hit a pair of critical free throws with 18 seconds remaining as Arizona held off a furious rally by Kansas for an 85-82 victory.

The Jayhawks (34-2), who had just one loss all season -- a narrow overtime defeat -- became the only regional top seed to fail to reach the elite eight after North Carolina fought off fifth-seeded California 63-57 in the East Regional semifinals at Syracuse, New York.
The other regional top seeds, Kentucky (West) and Minnesota (Midwest) advanced on Thursday.

Arizona (22-9) used its fast break speed to break open a tight game in the second half. Bibby nailed a three-pointer from the right baseline with 3:28 to play that put the Wildcats ahead by 13, 75-62.

Arizona still led by 10 with 1:52 to play when Kansas nearly pulled off a remarkable comeback with the help of a pair of steals and three successive three-pointers. The last trey by Ryan Robertson with 21 seconds left pulled Kansas within one at 83-82.
Bibby was fouled and made both his shots from the line to give the Wildcats their three-point cushion.
Kansas then had three desperation cracks at the tying three-pointer in the final seconds, but Billy Thomas missed from the left wing and Robertson came up short.
Raef LaFrentz got the rebound underneath and raced out beyond the three-point line, but his hurried shot from the left corner glanced off the rim at the buzzer.
Paul Pierce led Kansas with 27 points and LaFrentz and Robertson added 14 apiece.
Michael Dickerson chipped in 20 and Miles Simon added 17 for Arizona, a team with virtually no seniors that is now one win from the Final Four.
"It's so great for these kids. I'm just so proud of them, said Arizona coach Lute Olson.

"We had great quickness. They hurt us some with their size but... in the post the Kansas guys had to work their tails off to get the ball in there and I thought maybe that helped wear them down a little bit. I thought we were fresher in the end."
Olson's team will now face 10th-seeded Providence, the winner of a meeting between a pair of Cinderella teams.

Jamel Thomas hit three three-pointers in a 3:54 span late in the second half as Providence ended the surprising run of 14th-seeded Tennessee Chattanooga with a 71-65 victory in the second game at Birmingham.
Chattanooga had upset third-seeded Georgia and Providence shocked second-seeded Duke to set up the unlikely showdown.

Austin Croshere scored 19 points and God Shammgod added 15 for Providence (24-11). Johnny Taylor scored 22 and Chris Mims added 15 for Chattanooga (24-11), which was denied a chance to become the first 14th seed to reach the regional finals.
The game was tied 51-51 in the second half when Providence pulled away with a 15-2 run.
"We're thrilled we won but I don't know how we did it," said Providence coach Pete Gillen, who said his team got overly excited in the second half.
"We're thrilled with the win," Gillen said. "We've got to try to get better on Sunday otherwise Arizona will kill us."
At Syracuse, Antawn Jamison and Vince Carter combined for all the points in a 15-3 run as North Carolina rallied past surprisingly tough California.
Jamison finished with 21 points for the Tar Heels (27-6), who are one win from reaching their fourth Final Four this decade.
Randy Duck scored 15 points for California (23-9), which exceeded expectations by reaching the Sweet 16 without leading scorer Ed Gray, who broke his foot late in the regular season.
California used a 9-0 run to grab a 43-36 lead with 12:26 to play. But Jamison took control from the low post to spark the Tar Heels' second half rally.
"In many ways they were a better team than we were tonight but we won the game," said North Carolina coach Dean Smith.
In the East regional final North Carolina will play sixth-seeded Louisville, which pulled away for a 78-63 victory over 10th-seeded Texas.
Alvin Sims scored a career-high 25 points and Damion Dantzler made a pair of three-pointers in a game-breaking second-half run as Louisville (26-8) defeated Texas for the second time this season.
Louisville won despite losing point guard DeJuan Wheat, who had to be carried off the court with a severely sprained left ankle with 15:52 left.
"This was a great team effort that second half," said Louisville coach Denny Crum. "Without DeJuan, we don't have a ballhandler, we don't have a point guard, and everybody had to contribute."
The last time Louisville advanced to the regional finals was in 1986 when they went on to win the NCAA Tournament.
